department.ch: 認知神經科學研究所碩士班

goal.ch:
“This course is designed to provide a broad introduction to event-related brain potential (ERP) studies in cognition. Issues covered in this course include (1) the genesis of electroencephalography (EEG) and magnetoencephalography (MEG), (2) the recording of EEG/ERP, (3) design and analysis of ERP experiments, (4) ERP studies of human cognition. Students will also get hand-on experience by designing and conducting ERP experiments in their own projects.

Each week we will focus on one specific discussion topic, which is associated with a set of assigned readings. In the class there will be a general introduction for each topic followed by the reports of the readings assigned to you. The readings should be completed before the class. Assignments will be given when necessary, and you should complete them before due dates.

You will design and conduct an ERP experiment. The paradigm of the experiment will be discussed and decided by you and the instructor. There will be a project presentation in the last class.

outline.ch:
22nd February, Course Orientation, Overview, History of EEG/ERPs, EEG/ERP Database
29th February, Electrogenesis and Conceptual Issues of Cognitive ERP study
1.Chapters 1 ＆ 2 of Luck (2014)
2.Chapters 1 ＆ 2 of Rugg ＆ Coles (1995)
3.Baillet, S. (2017). Magnetoencephalography for brain electrophysiology and imaging. Nature neuroscience, 20(3), 327.
7th March, EEG/ERP Data Acquisition
1.Keil, A. et al. (2014). Committee report: Publication guidelines and recommendations for studies using electroencephalography and magnetoencephalography. Psychophysiology, 51, 1-21.
2.Chapters 5 ＆ 7 of Luck (2014)
3.Chapter 2, p24-58 of Hansen, Kringelbach, ＆ Salmelin (2010)
14th March, Design and Interpretation of ERP Experiments
1.Chapters 2 ＆ 4 of Luck (2014)
2.Chapter 1 of Luck ＆ Kappenman (2012)
3.Examples of language effects on ERP components (N400 and P2)
21st March, ERP Lab Practice
28th March, April, Data Processing, Signal Extraction, and Waveform Analysis I
1.Chapters 6,7,8,9 of Luck (2014)
2.EEGLAB/ERPLAB for data analysis
http://sccn.ucsd.edu/eeglab/
http://erpinfo.org/erplab
4th April, NO CLASS (Spring Break)
11th April, Data Processing, Signal Extraction, and Waveform Analysis II
18th April, Mid-term Exam
25th April Topographic Analysis
1.McCarthy, G. ＆ Wood, C. C. (1985). Scalp distributions of event-related potentials: An ambiguity associated with analysis of variance models. Electroencephalography and clinical Neurophysiology, 62, 203-208
2.Urbach, T.P. ＆ Kutas, M. (2002). The intractability of scaling scalp distributions to infer neuroelectric sources. Psychophysiology 39, 791–808.
3.Wilding, E. L. (2006). The practice of rescaling scalp-recorded event-related potentials. Biological Psychology 72, 325–332.
4.Chapter 7 of Luck (2005)
2nd May, Basics of Time-Frequency Analysis (I)
Background Readings:
1.Chapter 7 of Luck ＆ Kappenman (2012)
Readings for Discussion:
Chapter 3 of Kramer, M. A., ＆ Eden, U. T. (2016). Case studies in neural data analysis: A guide for the practicing neuroscientist. MIT Press.
9th May, Basics of Time-Frequency Analysis (II)
Background Readings:
1.Chapter 6 of Luck ＆ Kappenman (2012).
Readings for Discussion:
1.Jokisch, D., ＆ Jensen, O. (2007). Modulation of gamma and alpha activity during a working memory task engaging the dorsal or ventral stream. Journal of Neuroscience, 27(12), 3244-3251.
2.Tallon-Baudry, C., ＆ Bertrand, O. (1999). Oscillatory gamma activity in humans and its role in object representation. Trends in cognitive sciences, 3(4), 151-162.
3.Roach, B. J., ＆ Mathalon, D. H. (2008). Event-related EEG time-frequency analysis: an overview of measures and an analysis of early gamma band phase locking in schizophrenia. Schizophrenia bulletin, 34(5), 907-926.
16th May Proposal Presentation
23rd ~ 30th May, Paper Discussion
6th June: Project Presentation
22nd June: Term Paper Due (Please submit to ee-class before 11:00 PM)

1. Luck, S. J. (2014). An introduction to the event-related potential technique. Supplementary Readings:
